envMC.text: How would you see if you could connect to google.com?

options.text: ssh google.com
ps google.com
ping google.com
scp google.com

envMC.text: I want to learn all about the ls command and everything that it can do. Which command do I use to achieve that?

options.text: whatis ls
man ls
ifconfig ls
whereis ls

envMC.text: What does this command sequence do? Sequence: ps -fu user1 | grep pID, kill pID, jobs, bg pID

options.text: Looks for all the processes for a user and displays them, stops a process, lists status of all active processes
Looks for all the processes, stops a process, lists status of all processes, brings a process from the background to the foreground
Looks for all the processes for a user, suspends a process, lists status of all active processes, forces a process to run in the background
Looks for all the processes for a user and displays them, stops a process, lists status of all active processes, forces a process to run in the background

envMC.text: What command allows you to see the type of os a machine is running?

options.text: type -os
uname -a
who
ifconfig -a

envMC.text: You are in account U1. You want to switch users and access account U2. What are the steps that happen to achieve that?

options.text: Kernal, Hardware, Shell
whoami U2, set password, access account
su U2, access account
su U2, ask for password, access if correct
Suspends a process
Terminates a process
Terminates an external process
Suspends a job for an amount of time before temrinating it

envMC.text: What does ssh stand for and when would you use it?

options.text: socket shell, used when you need a secure connection between hosts
secure shell; used when you need to see if a host is available
secure shell; used when you need a secure connection between hosts
security shell; used when you need a secure connection between hosts

envMC.text: When would you use who vs. when would you use whoami?

options.text: Why would I ever use those commands?
Use who when you want to see who did a certain action, use whoami when you want to switch between users
Use whoami when you would like to see all logged in users' information; use who when you want to see current username
Use who when you would like to see all logged in users' information; use whoami when you want to see current username

envMC.text: What's the similarity and difference between scp and ssh?

options.text: Similarity: network protocols that can be used to exchange data through a secure channel between two remote devices in a network; Difference: scp is for transfering files and can use ssh, and ssh is for establishing a secure connection between two remote devices

Similarity: network protocols that can be used to exchange data through a secure channel between two remote devices in a network; Difference: ssh is for transfering files and can use scp, and scp is for establishing a secure connection between two remote devices
Similarity: network protocols that are both used for transfering files but in different ways; Difference: ssh provides a secure connection while scp provides a more unsecure connection

Similarities: file protocols that can be used to exchange data through a secure channel between two remote devices in a network; Difference: scp is for transfering files and can use ssh, and ssh is for establishing a secure connection between two remote devices

envMC.text: What is an environment variable and how do you see them?

options.text: Environment variables describe the environment is which programs and applications run; command: en
Environment variables describe the environment is which programs and applications run; command: env
Environment variables are variables used to store application data in; command: env
